'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-06-26 02:07:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Do not merge

I'm not sure I really agree with this.  If the API request was for a spice console, and we can't provide that, then an error makes sense to me.  Requesting spice and getting vnc seems wrong.

Interested in more opinions on this, though ..."}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-06-26 08:04:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

There's a few factors I hope can be considered:

1. If a user is requesting a console, I would be be surprised to hear they'd rather have no console as opposed to the one they requested.

2. The fact that we expose the exact console protocols via the API is confusing in the first place.  We compound this by having two (for libvirt) relevant API options, with arguments into those options (i.e. get-vnc-console novnc).  I'm fairly certain a user just wants a console which works and doesn't care if it's the specific one they requested or not, especially if the alternative is no console.

3. There is no migration path for getting onto Spice consoles today.  Most deployments had VNC enabled prior to Grizzly, since there was no other option and may have also turned on Spice with their Grizzly deployments.  As such, only *new* instances will have both consoles available, causing Spice requests on older instances to fail outright.

This is mainly an attempt to improve user experience and isn't the last step in this area.  Conceivably, we should consolidate all the console calls down to get-console (or similar) and let the cloud provider decide which is returned if there are multiple options."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-06-26 09:24:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

> This is mainly an attempt to improve user experience and isn't the last step in this area. Conceivably, we should consolidate all the console calls down to get-console (or similar) and let the cloud provider decide which is returned if there are multiple options.

The API is not the place to making user experience decisions. The APIs provide a canonical, predictable data source for information. The client application using the APIs already has the ability to handle priorization of VNC vs SPICE via the APIs, in order to satisfy whatever user experience they wish to expose. Horizon does this by trying to display a VNC console and if not available it will fall back to displaying a SPICE console. We cannot assume that all applications will want to automatically fallback from one protocol to the other protocol. So encoding such fallback behaviour in the API is categorically wrong. It must be left upto the client application to decide upon."}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-06-26 20:52:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Thanks for the feedback, it makes sense.

I'm going to refactor this patch to simply contain the proper exception handling for both console types and eliminate the fallback.  From there, we can have Horizon perform the fallback itself (it cannot currently)."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-06-27 09:23:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> From there, we can have Horizon perform the fallback itself (it cannot currently).

That's odd, because it certainly could fallback from VNC -> SPICE when I first submitted the code for SPICE support. So something must have broken it since :-("}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-06-27 23:06:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

It sort of works in Horizon.  The issue is that the ability to fall back is based on whether the target compute node has Spice and/or VNC enabled, not whether the *running instance* has Spice enabled.  In other words, environments which have a combination of pre-Grizzly and new VMs.'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-07-02 00:43:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-07-02 00:44:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Patch set 5 eliminates all of the fall back and simply raises exceptions, which will allow clients to handle this situation properly.'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-07-02 00:46:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-02 01:41:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

Bug 1192724

Updated the libvirt driver to return a proper exception when we are
unable to get the necessary info for Spice. Previously this would
result in a completely uncaught exception. The exception propagates
through to the console API extention, which has a configurable
option to fall back to VNC in the aforementioned case.

    New config option:
        auto_spice_fallback_to_vnc=True (default)

Change-Id: If06e726e606f4a27c8ec4617400b728ce7112e3b
Flags: DocImpact

commit_message:
Raise exceptions when Spice/VNC are unavailable

Bug 1192724

Both Spice and/or VNC may be enabled from the perspective of compute
configuration but their actual availability can vary based on
whether either was enabled/disabled at the time the instance was
launched. This patch raises a proper exception in this case, such
that clients (including Horizon) can either message the user or fall
back.

Change-Id: If06e726e606f4a27c8ec4617400b728ce7112e3b

used everytime, since the client is ignoring nova's --limit param). This should
decrease the number of queries that glance does when nova requests an image
detail list.

"}]
commit_message:
Increase default page_size value

This is a temporary solution. Increasing the default page size (which is being
used everytime, since the client is ignoring nova's --limit param). This should
decrease the number of queries that glance does when nova requests an image
detail list.

Bug 1200257

Change-Id: I7ed4521698570cbae9c20e69ddca8b11b57c65ad

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-29 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-07-11 17:06:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Restored'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2013-07-12 14:40:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't really have a lot of input on this other than to mostly parrot Sean's concerns. From an infrastructure/CI perspective anything which introduces more complexity for DevStack is additional surface area where bugs can sprout. On the other hand, I don't use DevStack outside of CI so maybe other viewers see more potential in the wrapper options."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-07-12 15:14:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I would like to analyze the random faulure issues on my dev machine.

An strace or pdb usually very helpful.

I do not want to restart the services after a devstack.
Since they are random issues, the manual restart is very time consuming.

What do you recommend for a simple service restart with a WRAPPER after a devstack install ?

My main concern with the post restart, it will be less close to the CI service starting.

I can use systemtap without a wrapper (It is system wide tracer), but I thought the WRAPPERS are useful for other persons who do not like systemtap.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-07-15 08:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

BTW: the ./unstack.sh does not stops the services, they are re-parented to the init.

Is it just happens on my system?'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-07-19 09:33:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-21 08:50:13.000000000', 'message': 'Add per service WRAPPER variables for debugging

The WRAPPER-<service-screen-name> variables can be defined
as an environment variable or they can be in the localrc.

You can use different wrappers with different
 options for different services.

Change-Id: I94e1a078d12f1e1b52030b25dc64aee106ceb783
'}]
commit_message:
Add per service WRAPPER variables for debugging

The WRAPPER-<service-screen-name> variables can be defined
as an environment variable or they can be in the localrc.

You can use different wrappers with different
 options for different services.

Change-Id: I94e1a078d12f1e1b52030b25dc64aee106ceb783

commit_message:
murano-git-install updated.

The script now can detect if remote branch is newer.
In this case local services will be restarted.

Change-Id: I74d66eb19662a0d5f62fe18227222320e3272905

commit_message:
Move url_for into heat_keystoneclient.

This allows faking of this call, and removes one instance of
accessing the encapsulated keystone client.

Change-Id: Iad2a9aaad2e9f1dc3cbeb509c822a61427f12817

commit_message:
Handle InstanceType change in Instance.handle_update

Make a resize API call against Nova if the InstanceType of an Instance
resource is change via a resource update.

Implements: blueprint instance-resize-update-stack
Change-Id: Ic4ee82edec842ee756b104a36dfef28bf3f89717

Of DHCP and L3 agents, NVP uses DHCP; This patch adds support
for the extension to this plugin, however L3 agent specific
methods are overriden to raise NotImplementedError.

With this patch we also avoid masking NotImplementedError(s).
Previously, a catch-all clause returned 500, and it makes
sense to distinguish between genuine 500 errors (i.e. a bug),
versus 501 ones.

This opens up the issue of keeping the server behavior
consistent from one release to another, but one might argue
that this was bad design decision in the first place.

commit_message:
Add support for the agent extension to NVP Plugin.

Of DHCP and L3 agents, NVP uses DHCP; This patch adds support
for the extension to this plugin.

This patch also moves some tests around, as a result of the
refactory done in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/35266/
Some code duplication is also removed.

Implements blueprint nvp-agent-scheduler-extension

Change-Id: I4ca1148e81fdb39bf6b58eef806536439e9f0c6f

 not the engine down time

[{'created': '2013-07-19 04:22:01.000000000', 'message': 'Do not evaluate data generated before heat engine started

The heat beats will not be written to database during heat engine is
stopped. When heat engine is started again, it looks at the heat beat
data stored in database, and found some heat beats missing so restart
the resources.

The solution is to evaluate only the data generated in current heat
engine session. For the data in previous session, current session does
not take action.

Change-Id: I537d9f4aa0750c6b771f6bc842e8137e1ab8606e
Fixes: bug #1202552
'}, {'created': '2013-07-19 04:29:23.000000000', 'message': 'Do not evaluate data generated before heat engine started

commit_message:
Do not evaluate data generated before heat engine started

The heat beats will not be written to database during heat engine is
stopped. When heat engine is started again, it looks at the heat beat
data stored in database, and found some heat beats missing so restart
the resources.

The solution is to evaluate only the data generated in current heat
engine session. For the data in previous session, current session does
not take action.

Change-Id: I537d9f4aa0750c6b771f6bc842e8137e1ab8606e
Fixes: bug #1202552

commit_message:
PCI passthrough Scheduler layer

Change HostState
  Now it contains also available pci labels

Add new filter PciPassthroughFilter:
  That checks that host has all required labels

Add new tests and fix old

blueprint pci-passthrough-base

Change-Id: I820d734e098b65910a3a0a44d176827ee9a868b9

commit_message:
PCI passthrough Utils layer

These utils are used for few things:

1) Functions that are used often:
get_labels_from_instance_type()
  It get labels as a list from json string which is in specific
  extra_spec in instance_type

check_pci_device_address()
Checks that address of pci deivce is in right format (by regex)

parse_address()
from address get tuple of (domain, bus, slot, function)

2) Sync nova.conf with DB state
sync_pci_devices()
*) Gets json string from nova confg param pci_passthrough_devices
*) Checks that it is well formated (by jsonschema schema validator)
*) Gets list of device from this json string (make object from json)
*) Check that there is no duplicated addresses in these devices
*) delete all devices in db on this host. (If device is used, change
   status to 'to_delete'). And this device will be deleted when instance
   will be destroyed.

resource tracker will call this on each compute_node_sync:
*) Try to create devices that are left
   (some of the device couldn't be created, because they are used)

blueprint pci-passthrough-base

Change-Id: Ie169b3f3925e9c0be734dd73ff043ab39dcbf1db

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-11 01:05:53.000000000', 'message': "Bring back dmsetup remove.

Heavy loads doing things like running delete on
hundreds of LVM volumes on a single cinder node
can result in some failures.

Particularly issues with iscsi tgt's, and what's
worse is you can end up in an error-deleting state
that you can't get out of because the tgt system
has the device as still in use.

Bring back dmsetup remove, but ignore situations where
it might fail, the worst that can happen here is that it
fails to remove the mapped device and it happens to still
be open and we have the same failure situation we
currently have.

Fixes bug: 1191960

Change-Id: Ie77886286723957561d4512d51abe8b64b32391f
"}]
commit_message:
Bring back dmsetup remove.

Heavy loads doing things like running delete on
hundreds of LVM volumes on a single cinder node
can result in some failures.

Particularly issues with iscsi tgt's, and what's
worse is you can end up in an error-deleting state
that you can't get out of because the tgt system
has the device as still in use.

Bring back dmsetup remove, but ignore situations where
it might fail, the worst that can happen here is that it
fails to remove the mapped device and it happens to still
be open and we have the same failure situation we
currently have.

Fixes bug: 1191960

Change-Id: Ie77886286723957561d4512d51abe8b64b32391f

commit_message:
Move tests into ceilometer package.

tests.* is a package in the global namespace and is not one that we
are providing. Also, as should be clear from ceilometer's consumption of
nova's tests, you never know who might want to consume your test suite.

Change-Id: I4372a261d0e38eb3818ed3b2e6ac42dea9a7679c

'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-07-03 08:50:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Personally, I am not sure we gain enough to warrant adding the extra complexity to a bit of the code that keeps breaking all the time. But I will leave that for others to decide.

There are lots of extra routes through the code added, but I don't see tests for them all yet.

Given how fragile this code can be, it would be good to see some heavy testing around to make sure we don't miss something."}, {'account_id': 7040, 'date': '2013-07-03 09:44:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hi John, thanks for your comments, I have been thinking this question for a while, I totally agree with you that adding extra logic might get the current code a little bit complex, but I haven't figured out a better idea except redesign the resize/migrate, considering time frame of the H release and backward compatibility, this might be a feasible way, for the test part, more tests will definitely be added."}, {'account_id': 7040, 'date': '2013-07-03 09:45:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7040, 'date': '2013-07-07 19:54:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-07-07 20:04:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I would -2 this if I could. I think maybe you have something messed up in your commit message around the change-id that is preventing Gerrit from letting us vote.

This changes the external API, which isn't okay. The complexity it adds just to have a different state represented is much more than we should take on just for admin users (which we can trust to know better). If we really needed to make this change (I don't think we do) there are easier, less invasive, and less fragile ways of doing so.

-2 from me, just as soon as I can vote on it."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-07 20:36:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Fix migrate and resize operation confusion issue.

The migrate and resize operation share the same code path as
well as instance status task status and notification messages
in current nova code base, somehow it might confuse the user
when he/she perform migrate but got VERIFY_RESIZE status, this
patch fixed this issue by seperate different instance status,
task status and notification messages between migrate and resize.

Fixed bug #1196416
Fixed bug #1194019

Change-Id: I0aa43ff085dfcd7bb6c665f0e25bbeb89aa549c7

[{'created': '2013-06-26 05:52:58.000000000', 'message': "Fix 'to integer' conversion of max and min count values

Until now when you used values non-integer to max_count and/or min_count the
coercion worked like: min_count = int(2.5) so min_count received 2 instead of
raise bad request.

Convert to string before coerce to int solves the problem since int coercion
cannot convert from a string which is not a perfect int.

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/test_servers.py

Change-Id: Ifaa9910e13614554d1769e71e8eba9587ec5a13b
(cherry picked from commit 6b3bba9141c7fdc4b00025f7e6ee8d980e41ec9a)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix 'to integer' conversion of max and min count values

Until now when you used values non-integer to max_count and/or min_count the
coercion worked like: min_count = int(2.5) so min_count received 2 instead of
raise bad request.

Convert to string before coerce to int solves the problem since int coercion
cannot convert from a string which is not a perfect int.

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/test_servers.py

Change-Id: Ifaa9910e13614554d1769e71e8eba9587ec5a13b
(cherry picked from commit 6b3bba9141c7fdc4b00025f7e6ee8d980e41ec9a)

My take is that we'd need to understand more before rushing into patching the behavior of how the config file gets updated, especially if that required the admin to explicitly tune a knob"}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2013-07-19 05:46:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Abandoned

Looks like replacing the existing configuration is the standard way to get a new configuration inside dnsmasq. At least libvirt is also doing it this way. I'll abandon this review because it looks that the issue with re-reading the new configuration is a very specific issue in our environment and that it's not a general issue."}]

utils.replace_file is used to write the new options/hosts. It first

"}, {'created': '2013-07-18 13:31:01.000000000', 'message': "add possibility to rewrite existing configurations

commit_message:
add possibility to rewrite existing configurations

Inside the methods _output_opts_file and _output_hosts_file the method
utils.replace_file is used to write the new options/hosts. It first
creates a temporary file and afterwards renames this temporary file to
the name of the destination file.

This patch adds the possibility to directly write the new configuration
into the existing files. That's necessary for some environments to not
change the existings inodes of the configuration files.

fixes bug #1202641

Change-Id: Ia697a2deeb9dd639ae3b7d0843fea60f83d9cde4

A failure to close files in a timely fassion means
that data is not necessarily written immediately
on Pythons which do not use reference counting
(e.g. PyPy).

Change-Id: I5d363249676032a025a22a67275c2eed3151b264
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure that files are always closed in the tests.

A failure to close files in a timely fassion means
that data is not necessarily written immediately
on Pythons which do not use reference counting
(e.g. PyPy).

Change-Id: I5d363249676032a025a22a67275c2eed3151b264

Since the neutron client can unset any attribute, ensure
we can handle empty routes as a way to clear the extraroutes
for the router.

Fixes bug #1202890

Change-Id: Ib240a42ba1075d9a410da904b3d3ae9e19b2d86e
'}]
commit_message:
Allow to clear extra routes in NVP

Since the neutron client can unset any attribute, ensure
we can handle empty routes as a way to clear the extraroutes
for the router.

Fixes bug #1202890

Change-Id: Ib240a42ba1075d9a410da904b3d3ae9e19b2d86e

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-17 13:52:15.000000000', 'message': 'LP specification name caching.

This updates our LP calls to obtain blueprint information so that
they run faster. Previously calling spec.name would cause an LP hit
for each spec. Given that we call lp.specification many times during
a reviewday run this was causing slow runtimes.

What we do now is just scrap the blueprint name off of the Spec URL
(thus avoiding an extra LP hit).

Change-Id: I4f2cbcc262973b02e3a13b9bba1edde53d5e6d9e
'}, {'created': '2013-07-17 13:56:10.000000000', 'message': 'LP specification name caching.

This updates our LP calls to obtain blueprint information so that
they run faster. Previously calling spec.name would cause an LP hit
for each spec. Given that we call lp.specification many times during
a reviewday run this was causing slow runtimes.

What we do now is just scrap the blueprint name off of the Spec URL
(thus avoiding many of the extra LP hits).

Change-Id: I4f2cbcc262973b02e3a13b9bba1edde53d5e6d9e
'}]
commit_message:
LP specification name caching.

This updates our LP calls to obtain blueprint information so that
they run faster. Previously calling spec.name would cause an LP hit
for each spec. Given that we call lp.specification many times during
a reviewday run this was causing slow runtimes.

What we do now is just scrap the blueprint name off of the Spec URL
(thus avoiding many of the extra LP hits).

Change-Id: I4f2cbcc262973b02e3a13b9bba1edde53d5e6d9e

commit_message:
Refactor and add tests for db_replicator

* Create class for testing _repl_to_not and replicate_object fuctions to
  prevent duplication code by adding all preparation into setUp function.
* Move existed test function which testin _repl_to_not and
  replicate_object into created classes.
* Add tests for replicate_object and _repl_to_node functions.

Change-Id: I75ac7c6f0230e71bfb24328e44c33734b520b4cd

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-15 14:59:25.000000000', 'message': 'Fix filtering aggregate metadata by key

Filtering by metadata key has no effect in the following two functions:

    aggregate_metadata_get_by_host
    aggregate_host_get_by_metadata_key

Rely on the explicit join instead of joinedload to load the _metadata
relationship in these functions (indicated by the contains_eager
option), so that filtering by key still applies when the metadata is
collected.

Fixes bug 1201283.

Change-Id: I3e44b5db8d67787bfa14f0e57d30a02a271a8833
'}]
commit_message:
Fix filtering aggregate metadata by key

Filtering by metadata key has no effect in the following two functions:

    aggregate_metadata_get_by_host
    aggregate_host_get_by_metadata_key

Rely on the explicit join instead of joinedload to load the _metadata
relationship in these functions (indicated by the contains_eager
option), so that filtering by key still applies when the metadata is
collected.

Fixes bug 1201283.

Change-Id: I3e44b5db8d67787bfa14f0e57d30a02a271a8833

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-15 07:19:42.000000000', 'message': 'Fix aggregate_get_by_host host filtering

aggregate_get_by_host never actually joins the _hosts relationship,
so aggregates with non-matching hosts are still included in the output.

This change adds the join and improves the tests to cover the bug.

Fixes bug 1201277.

Change-Id: I87ebfe3de193b9ae47e3a2c8350a49d9cc863fb0
'}]
commit_message:
Fix aggregate_get_by_host host filtering

aggregate_get_by_host never actually joins the _hosts relationship,
so aggregates with non-matching hosts are still included in the output.

This change adds the join and improves the tests to cover the bug.

Fixes bug 1201277.

Change-Id: I87ebfe3de193b9ae47e3a2c8350a49d9cc863fb0

commit_message:
Unimplemented pause should not change vm state on PowerVM

The instance of PowerVM does not support pause, but
after pause the instance, the state change to PAUSED,
it's unreasonable.

Change-Id: I4fb184388c37ea8708cdacc173dc1b2dbd4d1597
Fixes: bug #1202082

commit_message:
Code dedup in test_libvirt_vif

- externed common assertions to methods
- externed common parts to methods:
  - description of net data
  - description of mappings data
  - creating fakelibvirt connection
  - creating libvirt configuration
  - getting node from xml

bp nova-tests-code-duplication

Change-Id: Id12e196519473cce27a998e37f33ce584f703a4f

subject: Fix parse_transport_url when url has query string

Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2835, 'name': 'Brian Elliott', 'email': 'bdelliott@gmail.com', 'username': 'belliott'}, {'_account_id': 5511, 'name': 'Nikola Dipanov', 'email': 'ndipanov@redhat.com', 'username': 'ndipanov'}, {'_account_id': 7808, 'name': 'Xavier Queralt', 'email': 'xqueralt@gmail.com', 'username': 'xqueralt'}]

[{'account_id': 7808, 'date': '2013-07-16 09:26:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-07-16 09:27:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2013-07-16 09:30:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It would be good to have a bug for this.

Also I am wondering how come the tests weren't failing - it would be good to add tests that would, to prevent regression."}, {'account_id': 7808, 'date': '2013-07-16 09:49:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

There is a test for that in ParseTransportURLTestCase.test_query_string which is failing with python 2.7.5 but not with 2.7.3.

The thing is that between those two versions python changed urlparse's behavior and started to parse the query for all the schemes and not just the predefined ones in the library (See http://hg.python.org/cpython/rev/79e6ff3d9afd).

I think the fix is fine and that we can keep both checks."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-16 10:24:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-16 09:17:36.000000000', 'message': "Fix parse_transport_url when url has query string

In python 2.7 the query is extracted from the path and can be found in
in the 'query' member of ParseResult  while in python 2.6 it is left
unparsed in the path member.

Change-Id: Ic6afbe7b431e3eb9ff28d3c9b3fa35a52efb3fb6

commit_message:
Fix parse_transport_url when url has query string

In python < 2.7.4 the query string from an url is only parsed for the
schemes that the module knows about (not including 'qpid' and 'rabbit').
This behaviour was changed in python 2.7.4 and now it parses the query
string for all the schemes and doesn't appear any more in the path.

This change makes sure that we look for the query string in both members
(query and path).

See http://bugs.python.org/issue9374

Fixes bug #1202149

Change-Id: Ic6afbe7b431e3eb9ff28d3c9b3fa35a52efb3fb6

commit_message:
Update revision for rabbitmq

This commit updates the revision of rabbitmq to install for testing.

This revision was chosen for two reasons:

- later revisions remove the rabbitmq::server class
- later revisions do not support installing from your local distro (which
means you will likely get a version not tested with openstack)

Change-Id: Ic3fe0e672a84978b01bc7c9014dd701ecf2b0bde

commit_message:
Update rabbitmq dependency

This commit updates the revision of rabbitmq to install for testing.

This revision was chosen for two reasons:

- later revisions remove the rabbitmq::server class
- later revisions do not support installing from your local distro (which
means you will likely get a version not tested with openstack)

Change-Id: Id73e7c9b43c25dbb6300c69565de2178b1a2462b

commit_message:
Fix unit suffix and add no_suffix option.

In Cinder we've been using gibibytes, however
we have code in some places using Gigabytes, the brick
LVM code was one of those places.

This change sets the default suffix to gibibytes/mibibytes (1024 based)
and also provides an option to ommit the suffix from the response now
that we can say that we're consistent in what is expected.

Change-Id: Ib1ca12a3a8690899469420c751045d181f3d4096

commit_message:
Raise ValueError if sort_dir is unknown

Raise ValueError in case of KeyError, when sort_dir is not
'asc' or 'desc'.

ValueError while adding pagination has never been raised before,
because if sort direction was incorrect, KeyError has been
raised while adding sorting.

Change-Id: Ia0366dbdf38557c4e6a9307fb27c77fd1c1873c3

commit_message:
Add tests for cinder/common/sqlalchemyutils.py

Add test cases:
- test_paginate_query_no_pagination_no_sort_dirs - tests
sorting only
- test_paginate_query_no_pagination - tests sorting only
- test_paginate_query_attribute_error
- test_paginate_query_assertion_error
- test_paginate_query_assertion_error_2
- test_paginate_query - tests both sorting and pagination
- test_paginate_query_value_error - is skipped now

Change-Id: Ibec636bf23872d221bac17f6514fc97bd09c4e86

commit_message:
Fix HTTP response for PortInUse during boot

If an in use port is passed as a network parameter in the request, Nova API
should raise an HTTPConflict (409) error

Fixes bug #1160887

Change-Id: I60103610f9143f1c668927fe40d10a14b39b4c25

'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-07-14 14:40:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

jbresnahan, can you tell me what's the use case or scenario about this patch simply? What's the json file content which allow administrator expose out in your plan? thanks."}, {'account_id': 6493, 'date': '2013-07-15 08:03:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The JSON file schema is defined by the operator in a contract between the glance server and the glance client, it is opaque to glance and I would like to keep glance out of the business of defining it if at all possible.

An early use case is see is where nova-compute is the client.  nova-compute is preparing to download a glance URL and it get all of the locations and the meta-data associate with them.  If it finds a file:// url it may be able to directly access it (or copy it or hard link) but first it must make sure that it has access to the file system on which the advertised URL exists.  So in the meta-data would be something like this:

{ 
"mountpoint": "/usr/local/glance/images",
"fs-type": "nfs",
"nfshost": "thishost.org"
"namespace": "<some string that both sides understand>"
}


this would give the client enough context to understand how to access the advertised file system.

please note the above is just an example and surely has errors and is incomplete.'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-07-15 13:33:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Got it, make sense to.
One minor comment there John."}, {'account_id': 6493, 'date': '2013-07-15 16:50:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-15 17:38:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
File system store can send metadata back with the location.

This patch allows the glance operator to associate metadata with
the file system store.  The metadata will be returned to v2 users
with each location that was created by the file system store.  This
information can give clients context into how to consume the data.

The new configuration option: file system_store_metadata_file is
added.  This is a path to a JSON file.  The JSON document can
contain lists, dicts and unicode values only.

blueprint: direct-url-meta-data
blueprint: multiple-image-locations
docImpact
Change-Id: I3f040374455feb876e970a1813099598301774b5

commit_message:
Create an endpoint for nova api v3.

Supports both SQL and templated keystone backend.
Create an additional endpoint for nova api v3.
The service type is computev3.
The endpoint is similar to the v2 one but the version
part is "v3" rather than "v2", and it does not include
the tenantid anymore.

Fixes: bug #1191798
Change-Id: I86e4734c3a9e57f1dc68f1104449d7c041d6927d

commit_message:
fix name of scheduler_driver in produced nova.conf

Fixes bug #1202174.  The nova.conf config variable that configures which
scheduler to use is scheduler_driver, not compute_scheduler_driver.

Change-Id: I775cae40edc9f8f55177f9d95cdbaa9416c4bfcd

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-15 14:16:22.000000000', 'message': 'Fix IPAddress and CIDR type decorators

Use load_dialect_impl() user hook instead of calling
with_variant() on a type implementation in IPAddress
and CIDR type decorators. This makes this code work
with SQLAlchemy 0.8.x versions.

Fixes bug 1200231

Change-Id: Ib0eb582f472116bda817d3e35e26888dc116ad58
'}]
commit_message:
Fix IPAddress and CIDR type decorators

Use load_dialect_impl() user hook instead of calling
with_variant() on a type implementation in IPAddress
and CIDR type decorators. This makes this code work
with SQLAlchemy 0.8.x versions.

Fixes bug 1200231

Change-Id: Ib0eb582f472116bda817d3e35e26888dc116ad58

Agreed - I'm waiting for Gary to tell me how to reproduce the problem .  In my system the code seems to work as presented here.

Also open to other ideas on how to get the instance id from a floating IP."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-05 16:16:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

In order to try and get some more clarity here I went back to devstack and added tracing for the floating IP object returned by the client in the call to assign it to a fixed ip:   quantumv2/api.py/associate_floating_ip()

Heres the floating IP object returned from:  client.list_floatingips(floating_ip_address=address)  for on first assignment (i.e. before it gets assigned to any address)

 $ nova floating-ip-create
 +--------------+-------------+----------+--------+
 | Ip           | Instance Id | Fixed Ip | Pool   |
 +--------------+-------------+----------+--------+
 | 172.24.4.228 | None        | None     | public |
 +--------------+-------------+----------+--------+

 $ nova list
 +--------------------------------------+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
 | ID                                   | Name | Status | Task State | Power State | Networks         |
 +--------------------------------------+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
 | f5d19ca9-748f-44cd-91d1-b46355ad8a14 | phil | ACTIVE | None       | Running     | private=10.0.0.3 |
 +--------------------------------------+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+

 $ nova add-floating-ip f5d19ca9-748f-44cd-91d1-b46355ad8a14 172.24.4.228

fip = {u'router_id': None, u'tenant_id': u'5b456e3534a8458d8ca7d447bee39eb4', u'floating_network_id': u'a0452b5b-324f-4fed-bbd3-75c917f49e2c', u'fixed_ip_address': None, u'floating_ip_address': u'172.24.4.228', u'port_id': None, u'id': u'b0ba2c07-9643-485b-b26c-f0a8b74ec114'}

Note that the port_id at this point is set to None


Now heres the same floating IP object when its returned from client.list_floatingips(floating_ip_address=address)  after its been assigned to an instance:

 $ nova list
 +--------------------------------------+------+--------+------------+-------------+--------------------------------+
 | ID                                   | Name | Status | Task State | Power State | Networks                       |
 +--------------------------------------+------+--------+------------+-------------+--------------------------------+
 | 5c282af8-e3e5-4059-97cc-8e9fbd730d33 | phil | ACTIVE | None       | Running     | private=10.0.0.4               |
 | f5d19ca9-748f-44cd-91d1-b46355ad8a14 | phil | ACTIVE | None       | Running     | private=10.0.0.3, 172.24.4.228 |
 +--------------------------------------+------+--------+------------+-------------+--------------------------------+

 $ nova add-floating-ip 5c282af8-e3e5-4059-97cc-8e9fbd730d33 172.24.4.228

 (I.e. move it from 10.0.0.3 to 10.0.0.4)

fip = {u'router_id': u'fe5f8e87-40b5-4363-b871-ef442bc6b07b', u'tenant_id': u'5b456e3534a8458d8ca7d447bee39eb4', u'floating_network_id': u'a0452b5b-324f-4fed-bbd3-75c917f49e2c', u'fixed_ip_address': u'10.0.0.3', u'floating_ip_address': u'172.24.4.228', u'port_id': u'809e1892-8466-470a-9d69-8e79c80c638b', u'id': u'b0ba2c07-9643-485b-b26c-f0a8b74ec114'}

The port_id in this case is the port ID associated with the fixed IP it was assigned to 

 $ quantum port-list
 +--------------------------------------+------+-------------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
 | id                                   | name | mac_address       | fixed_ips                                                                       |
 +--------------------------------------+------+-------------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
 | 2b1dc81b-f43b-414b-9f04-449c99c9ee72 |      | fa:16:3e:8a:8b:32 | {"subnet_id": "cbe4529a-928f-4232-9e32-d38799822001", "ip_address": "10.0.0.1"} |
 | 7285f6ba-8357-4ed7-b86c-e9cb461fc59d |      | fa:16:3e:c1:7a:7a | {"subnet_id": "cbe4529a-928f-4232-9e32-d38799822001", "ip_address": "10.0.0.4"} |
 | 809e1892-8466-470a-9d69-8e79c80c638b |      | fa:16:3e:18:27:0c | {"subnet_id": "cbe4529a-928f-4232-9e32-d38799822001", "ip_address": "10.0.0.3"} |
 | fd39d64b-def6-4e0a-b7fa-c2f5298cebc6 |      | fa:16:3e:d5:78:79 | {"subnet_id": "cbe4529a-928f-4232-9e32-d38799822001", "ip_address": "10.0.0.2"} |
 +--------------------------------------+------+-------------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------+


So I cant see any evidence of the behavior that Gary thinks is there  i.e. floating IP objects point to their own port and not the port of the fixed IP they are associated with.

I'd really like to close this out either way - as it is tagged as a high priority bug'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-07-05 17:54:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi,
Sorry for taking a very long time on this one. At the moment I do not have a environment at my disposal, hopefully in a day or two.
When a port is assigned to a floating IP the device_id for the port is set to the the floating_ip ID: https://github.com/openstack/quantum/blob/master/quantum/db/l3_db.py#L653
I do not see how this can be the ID of an instance - line 542 in Phils code.
Sorry for the confusion.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-08 12:59:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Is it possible that the quantum client is substituting the port ID ?

Nova calls "list_floatingips" passing in the floating IP address as a parameter and  then takes the first (only I would guess) response.

I'm just wondering if the client (or maybe even the quantum API) is smart enough to know that what you'd really want is the port_id of any fixed IP the address is associated with and puts that into the return instead of the one that's associated with the flaoting_ip

I don't understand the structure of the quantum client well enough to know if this is true or not'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-08 17:19:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Looking into the quantum DB, the floating IP table has two port addresses:

 mysql> describe floatingips;
+---------------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+
| Field               | Type         | Null | Key | Default | Extra |
+---------------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+
| tenant_id           | varchar(255) | YES  |     | NULL    |       |
| id                  | varchar(36)  | NO   | PRI | NULL    |       |
| floating_ip_address | varchar(64)  | NO   |     | NULL    |       |
| floating_network_id | varchar(36)  | NO   |     | NULL    |       |
| floating_port_id    | varchar(36)  | NO   | MUL | NULL    |       |
| fixed_port_id       | varchar(36)  | YES  | MUL | NULL    |       |
| fixed_ip_address    | varchar(64)  | YES  |     | NULL    |       |
| router_id           | varchar(36)  | YES  | MUL | NULL    |       |
+---------------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+

It looks to me like the quantum client always returns the contents of fixed_pot_id in as the "port_id value:

mysql> select id,floating_ip_address,floating_port_id, fixed_port_id from floatingips;
+--------------------------------------+---------------------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+
| id                                   | floating_ip_address | floating_port_id                     | fixed_port_id                        |
+--------------------------------------+---------------------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+
| 9eba2bc8-8428-4c47-8856-42f3e8077c4d | 172.24.4.227        | f6cde722-e459-48d4-9ec9-da5a229d8ed2 | NULL                                 |
| b0ba2c07-9643-485b-b26c-f0a8b74ec114 | 172.24.4.228        | ce624cb7-0725-450d-a2f8-9feb26a492d0 | 7285f6ba-8357-4ed7-b86c-e9cb461fc59d |
+--------------------------------------+---------------------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+

$ quantum -v floatingip-list
DEBUG: quantumclient.client 
REQ: curl -i http://10.2.2.114:9696/v2.0/floatingips.json -X GET -H "X-Auth-Token: XXXX -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Accept: application/json" -H "User-Agent: python-quantumclient"

DEBUG: quantumclient.client RESP:{'date': 'Mon, 08 Jul 2013 17:10:04 GMT', 'status': '200', 'content-length': '613', 'content-type': 'application/json; charset=UTF-8', 'content-location': 'http://10.2.2.114:9696/v2.0/floatingips.json'} {"floatingips": [{"router_id": null, "tenant_id": "5b456e3534a8458d8ca7d447bee39eb4", "floating_network_id": "a0452b5b-324f-4fed-bbd3-75c917f49e2c", "fixed_ip_address": null, "floating_ip_address": "172.24.4.227", "port_id": null, "id": "9eba2bc8-8428-4c47-8856-42f3e8077c4d"}, {"router_id": "fe5f8e87-40b5-4363-b871-ef442bc6b07b", "tenant_id": "5b456e3534a8458d8ca7d447bee39eb4", "floating_network_id": "a0452b5b-324f-4fed-bbd3-75c917f49e2c", "fixed_ip_address": "10.0.0.4", "floating_ip_address": "172.24.4.228", "port_id": "7285f6ba-8357-4ed7-b86c-e9cb461fc59d", "id": "b0ba2c07-9643-485b-b26c-f0a8b74ec114"}]}

+--------------------------------------+------------------+---------------------+--------------------------------------+
| id                                   | fixed_ip_address | floating_ip_address | port_id                              |
+--------------------------------------+------------------+---------------------+--------------------------------------+
| 9eba2bc8-8428-4c47-8856-42f3e8077c4d |                  | 172.24.4.227        |                                      |
| b0ba2c07-9643-485b-b26c-f0a8b74ec114 | 10.0.0.4         | 172.24.4.228        | 7285f6ba-8357-4ed7-b86c-e9cb461fc59d |
+--------------------------------------+------------------+---------------------+--------------------------------------+


Which would maybe explain the confusion here - Quantum does indeed have a dedicated port per floating IP - but it also when assigned tracked the port ID of the fixed address its associated to - and the quantum API only includes the fixed_ip_port values as "port_id"  in a list of floating IPs (which is what the nova code is using)      

BTW quantum floatingip-show API also seems to map "fixed_port_id" in the DB to "port_id"'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-10 15:49:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I've found (I belive) the place in the quantum code where the floating_ip dict is constructed, and it shows that "port_id" is mapped from the fixed_ip_port, not the floating_ip_port

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/db/l3_db.py#L484-492

Gary - I believe this explains why the code works and returns the port the instance is attached to, and not the port created for the floating IP.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-07-10 18:22:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hi,
Sorry my bad. The code is good. My mistake was that I thought that we were looking at the device_id from the floting ip and not the port.
Please note that this will require a rebase due to the neutron namechange
Sorry\
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-07-10 21:28:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

the network info cache is always refreshed due to the

However if you (re)associate a floating IP which is already

commit_message:
Refresh network cache when reassigning a floating IP in Neutron

When Nova associates or disassociates a floating IP address
the network info cache is always refreshed due to the
@refresh_cache decorator

However if you (re)associate a floating IP which is already
associated with another instance on a Neutron based system then
the address is correcly disassociated first, but the cache refresh
is not trigged for the original  instance. As a result Nova will
show the same address for two instances until the periodic
clean-up kicks in some minutes later.

Fixed bug: 1173227

Change-Id: Iea81532911478026b9b2c0578a1eda7a97b09d80

commit_message:
Accept trailing /'s on URLs.

The API should accept trailing slashes.  The werkzeug map rule strict
slashes is set to False to allow trailing slashes.  The tests have
been updated using mock methods to verify that the api accepts the
call and then calls central service.
Fixes: bug 1202411

commit_message:
Remove redundant if statements in cells.state

Removed redundant if statements since checking if cell is None twice
was not intuitive.

Change-Id: I20d7ade5acd27d23ba53ef065d0e4d24218182c2

commit_message:
port disk_config API into v3 part1

This changeset only copies the v2 files into the appropriate v3
directories unchanged. The copy as-is will not be loaded by either
the v2 or v3 extension loaders. The second changeset will then
make the changes required for it to work as a v3 extension.

This is being tried in order to make reviewing of extension
porting easier as gerrit will display only what is actually
changed for v3 rather than entirely new files.

Partially implements: bp v3-api-extension-versioning

Change-Id: Ia2ef4ab8cb63878d16360378c61e5182f4593200

commit_message:
Sync v2/v3 console_output API extensions

Synchronises changes made to the v2 version of the console_output
API extension to v3 in commit c651f4928c65407cff86a9f9efc046a0f76a9519
which fixed bug  #1194032

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: Ie28d771d25636decb7b1f17756654be56762b35f

commit_message:
Allow tenant ID for authentication

Tenant names are not necessarily unique for a User, so the client
should also allow authentication by tenant_id

If both ID and Name are specificed then use the ID

Fixes bug 1195454

Change-Id: Ib62aabc3702db88f02259cd721f9efb31404bcb7

[{'created': '2013-07-18 18:18:53.000000000', 'message': "Make H103 Invalid Apache throw error on correct line

H103 shouldn't trigger on the first line of a file, but rather on the
first line of the apache licence in the file.  Otherwise the error can
be confusing to users.

Change-Id: Ib0f49d50c9541dd93ace6dd29361e143eb0b6828
"}]
commit_message:
Make H103 Invalid Apache throw error on correct line

H103 shouldn't trigger on the first line of a file, but rather on the
first line of the apache licence in the file.  Otherwise the error can
be confusing to users.

Change-Id: Ib0f49d50c9541dd93ace6dd29361e143eb0b6828

the user should say so.

python3 easier.

commit_message:
Avoid dropping cpu_util for multiple instances.

Fixes bug 1202756

When multiple instances exist, the ordering of pipleline
handle_sample() and flush() calls on the transformer caused
cpu_util samples for subsequent instances to be dropped.

Change-Id: I1d8198c0c12d99a2ffde11e4321d29723c947178

commit_message:
Update the ML2 README file with the latest tunnel changes

The ML2 README file was slightly out of date with all of the H2 changes
which went in around GRE and VXLAN tunneling. This patch updates it to
reflect what the code is capable of currently.

Fixes bug 1202743.

Change-Id: I578c1b62115f298c9de32d62161171fd2f3f5b7c

commit_message:
Make compute_api.reboot() use objects

This makes the compute api's reboot() method use objects and pass
them to compute/manager.

The one place we call back from compute/manager to compute/api's
reboot() is also converted to use objects in this patch. That
almost makes bug 1196301 go away, but will require instance
actions work as well.

This also adds a new cells method for passing the object to reboot in
the child cell.

Related to blueprint compute-api-objects

Change-Id: I7845daa266687b5dc24fc2b1a98f2e5a2841e4bf

commit_message:
Enhance VMware Hyper instance disk usage.

When build a instance, extend the root disk to instance flavor
specific size and add support for ephemeral disk.

Implement blueprint improve-vmware-disk-usage

Change-Id: I62e2967e1ef2e85ec653d75d3b3a90aeb9331400

I thought UUID was largely getting deprecated in keystone because it causes 6x times the traffic to the db?'}, {'account_id': 5174, 'date': '2013-07-17 14:22:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1613, 'date': '2013-07-17 14:41:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sean, 
PKI is the default now. UUID format through Devstack was working up until the pluggable token provider blueprint : https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33858/

Now the extra flag needs to be set.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-07-18 12:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This looks like a workaround for a bug in keystone :(

If the token_format is explicitly set to UUID, we should be setting the provider automatically to provide backwards compatibility.

Opened a bug to track provide a fix in keystone: https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1202651'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-07-18 14:56:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

[{'created': '2013-07-16 01:12:44.000000000', 'message': 'UUID Token provider in keystone.conf

Token provider needs to be set to uuid.Provider when the token format is
UUID. PKI is the default.

Change-Id: I967289524a50f650cdf2476d5067d263dbf55b03
Fixes: bug #1201639
'}]
commit_message:
UUID Token provider in keystone.conf

Token provider needs to be set to uuid.Provider when the token format is
UUID. PKI is the default.

Change-Id: I967289524a50f650cdf2476d5067d263dbf55b03
Fixes: bug #1201639

commit_message:
Check that the configuration file sample is up to date

We added this check recently to Ceilometer, and it helps a lot to keep this
file always up to date and not falling behind.

Change-Id: I5ad2c6366032a39c2e55dd11a16b9f1780ab9ed0

commit_message:
Move the getsources hook earlier.

Caching PyPI objects will require inspecting the content downloaded by
the source repositories, so needs to run after it.

Change-Id: I551c075e0bb6853b2ef79268b7f6455a4f06743d

commit_message:
Support token_format for backward compatibility

The provider property in the [token] section will be unset by default. If
provider is not set, we will use token_format in the [signing] section to
determine to provider. If provider is set, it must agree with the token_format.

fixed bug 1202651

Change-Id: I15ff67490acbbacc9eefc7eee253400475704b04

commit_message:
Add example Apache config files

This patch is needed in 1.9 as a dependency for adding swift/apache
to devstack.
zhang-hare is working in parallel on a devstack patch that depend
on this patch.

As part of this patch we add examples dir.
In this dir we add template config files that can be used either by
a script (as will be done by devstack) or serve a an example to the
admin.

Apache2 vhost files were added under examples/apache2
Wsgi files were added under examples/wsgi

Fixes: Bug #1191388

Change-Id: If90e38a0ba36f6b59016d4a1374f4100f0bbee7b

[{'created': '2013-07-18 15:00:25.000000000', 'message': "Forklift the DiskFile interface into it's own module

 * new module swift.obj.diskfile

I parameterized two constants from obj.server into the DiskFile's __init__

 * DATADIR -> obj_dir
 * DISALLOWED_HEADERS -> disallowed_metadata_keys

I'm not sure if this is the right long term abstraction but for now it avoids
circular imports.

Change-Id: I3962202c07c4b2fbfc26f9776c8a5c96292ae199
"}]
commit_message:
Forklift the DiskFile interface into it's own module

 * new module swift.obj.diskfile

I parameterized two constants from obj.server into the DiskFile's __init__

 * DATADIR -> obj_dir
 * DISALLOWED_HEADERS -> disallowed_metadata_keys

I'm not sure if this is the right long term abstraction but for now it avoids
circular imports.

Change-Id: I3962202c07c4b2fbfc26f9776c8a5c96292ae199

commit_message:
Pass all identity headers received to glance

There is an upcoming patch in nova which passes identity
headers to glance client. We want to ensure that these get
passed to glance, which in turn with help the no auth
option in glance.

Resolves bug 1200761

Change-Id: Ifbef582aa4e64a2e7a46db43a9cc6cf8c3531dbd

commit_message:
Support token_format for backward compatibility

The provider property in the [token] section will be unset by default. If
provider is not set, we will use token_format in the [signing] section to
determine to provider. If provider is set, it must agree with the token_format.

fixed bug 1202651

Change-Id: I15ff67490acbbacc9eefc7eee253400475704b04

commit_message:
run_stress.py -h doesn't work without a connection

run_stress.py tries to connect to openstack even though it's just a
--help / -h call. Just moved the import to the corresponding function.

Implements: blueprint stress-tests

Change-Id: Id0f9784a64f3bf53ea91a67452a78d17389d7f51

The standard way to create sample config files for each project is to
run the generate_sample.sh file under each projects virtualenv created by
tox or run_tests.sh. However this method has problems with projects
using openstack.nose because the openstack package from openstack.nose will

with projects using openstack.nose because the "openstack" package

creation on oslo to avoid this problem.

commit_message:
Adds virtualenv flag to sample config file generator

The standard way to create the sample config file for each project
is to run the generate_sample.sh file under each project's virtualenv
created by tox or run_tests.sh. However this method has a problem
with projects using openstack.nose because the "openstack" package
from openstack.nose will shadow the "openstack" package located
in the base directory of oslo-incubator since the virtualenv
has higher priority. This patch provides a flag to enable virtualenv
creation on oslo to avoid this problem.

Change-Id: I898afac5d306b424e28451606189dcb2e36b7234

This adds a config variable, so needs DocImpact in the commit message. (that's the crux of my -1)

My only question is if we should even bother letting this be configurable. If everyone wants it the other way, it's defaulted the other way, we're already compressing in other ways, what's the reason for even leaving it at all? Is there any compatibility reason why we'd care to change the default?

I'm +2 on the approach, think we should probably just go further on it."}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-06-17 11:47:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-06-17 11:47:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-06-17 11:54:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Sean, thanks for your review -- I added 'DocImact' to the commit message.

I think its worth having the param be configurable -- we are changing the default to suit most cases but there may be some people for whom the current behaviour is more performant (eg if you tend to use highly compressible images). Allowing the ability to toggle makes it easier for people to do performance analysis. (And the difference can be quite large, eg: http://15.185.160.228/ssl_comp.pdf)"}, {'account_id': 6896, 'date': '2013-06-17 11:57:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

[{'created': '2013-06-11 12:53:53.000000000', 'message': "Allow disabling ssl compression for glance client

Add a new parameter 'glance_api_ssl_compression' which allows
disabling ssl layer compression negotiation for glance requests.

commit_message:
Disable ssl layer compression for glance requests.

This may improve data throughput, eg when high network bandwidth is
available and you are using already compressed image formats such as
qcow2 .

Addresses bug 1189887.

Change-Id: Iacc42d8e0cab218258c3029d5395e02fddb75197

commit_message:
xenapi: no glance upload retry on 401 error

It is possible for a token to expire during a very long image upload.
If this happens, there is little point in retrying the upload, as it
is most likely to fail again for the same reason.

Fixes bug 1199454

Change-Id: Id699135a8ec4c603671b16f0127d0b2cd2a55855

subject: Create key manager interface
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 428, 'name': 'Robert Esker', 'email': 'esker@me.com', 'username': 'esker'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1007, 'name': 'Nathanael I Burton', 'email': 'nathanael.i.burton.work@gmail.com', 'username': 'mathrock'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2417, 'name': 'Ben Swartzlander', 'email': 'ben@swartzlander.org', 'username': 'bswartz'}, {'_account_id': 4992, 'name': 'malini-k-bhandaru', 'email': 'malini.k.bhandaru@intel.com', 'username': 'malini-k-bhandaru'}, {'_account_id': 6783, 'name': 'Nathan Reller', 'email': 'nathan.s.reller@gmail.com', 'username': 'rellerreller'}, {'_account_id': 6802, 'name': 'Joel Coffman', 'email': 'jmc7tp@gmail.com', 'username': 'joel-coffman'}, {'_account_id': 6804, 'name': 'bruce-benjamin', 'email': 'bruce.benjamin@jhuapl.edu', 'username': 'bruce-benjamin'}, {'_account_id': 7063, 'name': 'Robert Clark', 'email': 'hyakuhei@gmail.com', 'username': 'hyakuhei'}, {'_account_id': 7354, 'name': 'Jarret Raim', 'email': 'jarret.raim@rackspace.com', 'username': 'jraim'}, {'_account_id': 7370, 'name': 'Bill Becker', 'email': 'bill.becker@safenet-inc.com'}, {'_account_id': 7747, 'name': 'Subhash Sankuratripati', 'email': 'subhash@gmail.com', 'username': 'subhash'}, {'_account_id': 7764, 'name': 'Peter Hamilton', 'email': 'peter.hamilton@jhuapl.edu', 'username': 'Peter'}, {'_account_id': 7789, 'name': 'John Wood', 'email': 'john.wood@rackspace.com', 'username': 'woodster'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 428, 'date': '2013-05-31 15:24:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hello Joel,

One of the comments in the blueprint (by Duncan Thomas) points out that encrypting solely at Nova obviates many of the storage efficiency features present on certain Cinder backends (things like efficient cloning, deduplication, et cetera).  These backends themselves often provide a built-in encryption capability.  What's the plan to accommodate these as an alternative?

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 6802, 'date': '2013-05-31 16:38:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Our existing design does not preclude Cinder from providing its own support for encrypted volumes. If such support is added to Cinder, then configuration options would specify which implementation(s) to use by default.'}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2013-06-01 00:21:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It seems to me that the hardest part of any key management system is the decision making process for who gets access to which keys. Obviously a key management system that shares every key with everyone will work great for encrypting and decrypting data, but it won't be secure.

I'd like to understand how this key management system distinguishes between clients who should have access to the keys and clients who shouldn't. How is the client identifier passed to the key management server? How does the key management server know which clients should be authorized and which shouldn't?

We need to end up at a place where a given cinder/nova node can access the keys for the volumes that it owns and nothing else."}, {'account_id': 6802, 'date': '2013-06-03 15:17:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Agreed, Ben. This patch isn't proposing a key management system but rather an *interface* that will allow KMIP or Barbican to be plugged in as desired by the cloud provider. (The mock key manager included in this submission is only to facilitate testing the interface.)

The various key manager methods all accept a context object to identify the client that is requesting access to the key. The context contains a Keystone token that should be used for authorization. A first iteration might only verify that the client owns (or has permission to access) the key. Later versions could perform additional validation -- e.g., ensuring that the compute host accessing a volume's encryption key is also the volume's attach point.

I think that most of the questions you raised are ultimately the responsibility of the key management system, which is *not* our current focus. We want to settle upon an interface that allows various key management systems to be pluggable. At this point, we're really trying to understand if any additional methods or parameters must be added to this interface to answer your questions (e.g., to determine which nodes should have access to a particular key)."}, {'account_id': 7370, 'date': '2013-06-05 20:27:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

A couple minor comments:
1) You may want to consider changing the name delete_key to destroy_key to be consistent with the key mgmt terminology used in KMIP and NIST SP800-57 part 1.
2) Is there a need to include a register_key function? If the client needs to register a key that it generated locally? Or it is trying to move the key from one key manager (get_key) to another key_manager (register_key)?'}, {'account_id': 6802, 'date': '2013-06-05 21:51:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

Soliciting feedback regarding the key manager *interface* to allow multiple backends (e.g., Barbican or KMIP).'}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2013-06-06 03:44:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Joel, I think you may have answered my question without knowing it. If the plan is to pass the keystone token in the context object, then explains how the key manager knows who's asking for access, and I can imagine how we can ensure that the right things happen between nova+cinder so that only keys are only shared with the services that need them by using the keystone tokens."}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-06-06 11:16:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hello Joel!

Have you had a chance to look at: https://github.com/cloudkeep/python-barbicanclient/blob/master/barbicanclient/client.py

There is a little ways to go for the two to converge!
ctx to hold authentication credentials is good, really all things user. Auth_token (for keystone)  Barbican would seek to validate it against keystone and in so doing generate a context containing tenant-id etc among other things. 

While your "key" is barbican's secret, and barbican chose secret to disambiguate between keys such as private and public, key is general. A uuid should lock us down the key be it symmetric/private/public/whatever.

We certainly need the API to pass in key-length. Occassionally an algorithm will be adequate to determine keylength but at others one may have a choice of keylengths.

These additional parameters could be keyword args with defaults that are documented.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-21 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-21 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

'}, {'account_id': 7063, 'date': '2013-07-18 08:16:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Is there any intention for this to include asymmetric keypairs? At the moment I'm not clear how they would be stored, presumably as completely separate keys?

The requirement is somewhat important when you consider the key manager, it's looking at contexts, it's not hard to see when a request for a public key makes sense for an anonymous context but obviously the request for a private key would require a very specific context."}, {'account_id': 6802, 'date': '2013-07-18 12:33:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

At the moment, no, we haven't created classes for asymmetric keys although supporting them should be straightforward. The Key interface is based on Java's (see http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/security/Key.html), which supports asymmetric key pairs.

The key manager could store the public and private keys separately (i.e., with different UUIDs) so the private key isn't accessible by anonymous contexts."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2013-07-18 15:26:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I think it's ok to merge this in. Regarding the asymmetric key stuff, the blueprint is wide open and anyone is free to augment it. The existing specification doesn't mention anything explicit about them either, so I think the patch provides an appropriate implementation"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-18 15:27:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: No score

commit_message:
Create key manager interface

This interface provides a thin wrapper around an underlying key management
implementation such as Barbican or a KMIP server. The key manager interface is
used by the volume encryption code to retrieve keys for volumes.

Implements: blueprint encrypt-cinder-volumes
Change-Id: I9b0dcb7d648ee6809185c71ba457c8a8a6c90d50
SecurityImpact

commit_message:
Add decorator to make ABCs out of classes.

Rationale:

Creating abstract base classes in a way that works correctly for both
Python 2 and Python 3 has not yet been addressed. This module adds a
simple decorator that can be applied to any class and sets the
metaclass of that class to be abc.ABCMeta.

Tests are provided that demonstrate expected behavior for all
supported platforms.

*Note*: Running the tests on Python 3 took some finagling. I had to:

1. Create a py3.3 virtualenv
2. Removes several deps from requirements.txt and test-requirements.txt
3. Install nose.
4. Run `nose tests/unit/test_abcutils`

Until python 3 is working for all of the oslo dependencies, running
automated tests on abcutils is going to be a challenge.

Change-Id: Ib7074cf3777529afb8f100da1dc87516b4cd8011

commit_message:
Add Neutron chapter to API reference page

All wadls and samples were there, just needed to modify the
api-ref.xml file to show new sections. Also replaced 'quantum'
instances with 'neutron'.
Builds OK locally.
patchset 4 - diane fleming - fixed merge conflict in api-ref.xml

Fixes bug 1200718

Change-Id: I2840aa69d85e515689346cbf43423723850fe96f

commit_message:
Tidy up the SSH call to avoid injection attacks in storwize_svc

Let the command and arguments form up a list and avoid the extra arguments
attackers inserted to the command string

fix bug 1192971

commit_message:
Cache repository-sources data.

Cloning large repositories over the internet can take considerable
time.  Caching them locally makes repeated image builds significantly
faster, so lets do that.

When users override the element source they will often be using a
local repository, so in those cases I don't cache - but we could
easily change our minds on that in the future.

Change-Id: I9822362cf722b904d9806dbbb4bb07cfe2b33437

commit_message:
Forklift the DiskFile interface into it's own module

 * new module swift.obj.diskfile

I parameterized two constants from obj.server into the DiskFile class

 * DATADIR -> obj_dir
 * DISALLOWED_HEADERS -> disallowed_metadata_keys

I'm not sure if this is the right long term extraction but for now it avoids
circular imports.

Change-Id: I462fafa2638dcbdc628a1fa710e98bae04e8b4dc

subject: Change EC2 client tokens to use system_metadata
messages: [{'account_id': 6661, 'date': '2013-07-18 14:21:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned\n\nThis isn't getting picked up by the CI for some reason. Abandoning and resubmitting."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-18 14:11:39.000000000', 'message': "Change EC2 client tokens to use system_metadata

An EC2 client token is created as a result of RunInstances. The initial
implementation called create_tags which uses per-instance metadata.
However, we can't update per-instance metadata while an instance is still
building because put the metadata updates in the messaging queue.

We avoid this problem by using system_metadata instead of per-instance
metadata. As an added bonus, users can't tamper with the token via the tags
API.

Fixes bug #1202404

Change-Id: Ia904e75bce152fb1ee9c3929f7a0e2289781dfbb
"}]
commit_message:
Change EC2 client tokens to use system_metadata

An EC2 client token is created as a result of RunInstances. The initial
implementation called create_tags which uses per-instance metadata.
However, we can't update per-instance metadata while an instance is still
building because put the metadata updates in the messaging queue.

We avoid this problem by using system_metadata instead of per-instance
metadata. As an added bonus, users can't tamper with the token via the tags
API.

Fixes bug #1202404

Change-Id: Ia904e75bce152fb1ee9c3929f7a0e2289781dfbb

commit_message:
Remove Costs from the 'Weights and Costs' Chapter

Costs are no longer used in the scheduler, so Weights chapter is
updated with the remaining ram_weight_multiplier option.

Fixes bug 1172264

Cherry-picked from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30970

Change-Id: Ic8c57b2107c1e334acb1adfe3498d33fde7b435d

Replaced empty inheritance hierarchy with testscrenarios

Implements blueprint db-tests-with-scenarios

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-10 13:48:24.000000000', 'message': 'Move synchronized body to a first-class function

synchronized is being widely used throughout OpenStack for managing
locks by decorating methods / functions. However, it's funcionality is
trapped within that decorator definition and makes it difficult to
manage locks by using it in other cases (like w/o decorating).

This patch moves decorator's body into a first-class function called
lock which is intended to be used as a context manager type (with
statement).

Some examples:

    with lockutils.lock("test") as sem:
        print('Inside the lock')

Things I'm not 100% convinced:

    * The `lock` function yields a Semaphore when external is False and
    an InterProcessLock instance otherwise. Although it is not 'good' to
    yield different values depending on the input parameters, it's
    pretty explicit (by reading the documentation) that external locks
    are handled differently. Other options for this case are:

        1. Always yield a Semaphore instance
        2. Don't yield anything

The patch doesn't break backward compatibility so no change is needed to
existing projects.

This patch is needed as part of the blueprint cache-backend-abstraction

Change-Id: I96b2ee84da5a2dcd7f0bd469f8a1e52b74e50c75

commit_message:
Move synchronized body to a first-class function

synchronized is being widely used throughout OpenStack for managing
locks by decorating methods / functions. However, it's functionality is
trapped within that decorator definition and makes it difficult to
manage locks by using it in other cases (like w/o decorating).

This patch moves decorator's body into a first-class function called
lock which is intended to be used as a context manager type (with
statement).

Some examples:

    with lockutils.lock("test") as sem:
        print('Inside the lock')

Things I'm not 100% convinced:

    * The `lock` function yields a Semaphore when external is False and
    an InterProcessLock instance otherwise. Although it is not 'good' to
    yield different values depending on the input parameters, it's
    pretty explicit (by reading the documentation) that external locks
    are handled differently. Other options for this case are:

        1. Always yield a Semaphore instance
        2. Don't yield anything

The patch doesn't break backward compatibility so no change is needed to
existing projects.

Implements blueprint cache-backend-abstraction

Change-Id: I96b2ee84da5a2dcd7f0bd469f8a1e52b74e50c75

commit_message:
python3: Add basic compatibility support.

Add python2/python3 compatibility support:

- Change basestring to use six.string_type so that
six will either use str() or basestring().
- Use six.iteritems to replace dictionary.iteritems() on
python2 or dictionary.items() on python3.

Change-Id: I3a8eb1ba5b2fb2859169299d37ae6eeb9bb4cac0
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-12 18:32:32.000000000', 'message': 'python3: Add basic python3 compatibility.

Use six.text_type to replace unicode() in python2
and str in python3.

Change-Id: I61e961248241014380ec464429f2585a9497333b
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
python3: Add basic python3 compatibility.

Use six.text_type to replace unicode() in python2
and str in python3.

Change-Id: I61e961248241014380ec464429f2585a9497333b
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Remove the unused notifier.add_driver() API

This was only needed to support the plugins framework which is now
removed.

Change-Id: Id3d08c23f7791bfef9739f1f65af844fd429777c
